_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Rancho Murieta Community Services District (RMCSD) prepared a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Wastewater Reclamation Facility following California Code of regulations (CCR) title 19, Division 5, Chapter 2 § 5050.1, California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and federal Risk Management Plan regulations in 40 CFR Part 68. The RMP includes descriptions of the prevention program elements, equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with the regulated substance (RS); results of the offsite consequences analysis from a worst-case and alternative release; and emergency response program.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
It is the policy of RMCSD that the receipt, storage and handling of chlorine at its facilities be done in a manner which meets regulatory requirements and minimizes the probability and severity of releases of chlorine to the atmosphere, to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public and the environment. RMCSD has an emergency action plan to manage emergency situations and has coordinated emergency response actions with emergency response agencies.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
RMCSD produces, treats and distributes domestic water and provides wastewater collection and reclamation services.  Its administrative offices are located at 15160 Jackson Highway, Rancho Murieta, in Sacramento County. RMCSD uses chlorine, a regulated substance (RS), at the wastewater reclamation facility processes water for treating irrigation water for the golf course during the spring, summer, and fall months. Chlorine is maintained onsite during these months only. Predictive filing is used for this RMP whether chlorine is physically present or not.


General Accidental Release Prevention Programs
RMCSD implements general accidental release prevention programs following the Risk Management Program prevention program elements. 

Chemical Specific Release P

revention Steps
Release prevention steps specific to chlorine include installation of chlorine leak detectors and alarm telemetry at the sites, facility specific procedures for ton container receiving, transport, hookup, and leak response; and installing seismic restraint systems for the chlorine ton containers. 

Five Year Accident History
There have been no accidents involving chlorine at RMCSD facilities in Sacramento County within the past five years which resulted in injuries or offsite effects. 

Emergency Response Program
RMCSD will not respond to uncontrolled releases of chlorine.  RMCSD relies on outside responders to mitigate the release. RMCSD has written an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) applicable to chlorine which consists of actions related to chlorine release emergencies, activating the EAP, evacuation of Facility personnel to designated assembly points, and notification of emergency response agencies. RMCSD has coordinated its emergency response program with the local response agencies.  RMCSD's sites are included in the Sacramento County area plan.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Improvements and mitigation measures from the process hazardous analysis include relocating or installing a protective cover over the process e-stop button to reduce the potential for accidental activation and performing a new seismic assessment. RMCSD is committed to inherently safer technology and is in the process of moving from the use of chlorine gas to sodium hypochlorite.
